metadata.synopsis: Gene Roddenberry wrote and produced this black comedy about a guidance counselor well-versed in seduction and murder.

reviews: Gathering together the distinguished selection of Hudson, Dickinson, and Savalas for a story so deliciously eccentric is perhaps its greatest success.
Pretty Maids All in a Row simply shares the ineffable vulgarity it portrays.
Were you to take out the sex and nudity, it would be nothing but an incomprehensible load of silliness.
I won't say that Pretty Maids All in a Row is a good film by any traditional measure. It is, however, a genuine curio.
A scalding satire and, all things considered, a remarkably fecund work
At best, it can be viewed as silly fun and harmless soft core porn that offers a snapshot of a bygone era.
Weird mix of teen comedy and slasher film.
The movie itself is, finally, embarrassing. It's embarrassing because Vadim's personal hang-ups don't fit the nature of his material, and so he tries to bend things.
In 1971 this was pretty daring and trendy. Unfortunately, it's no longer 1971.
Pretty Maids All in a Row is the first American film for French director Roger Vadim. If we are lucky it may be his last.
